page.title: 01Healey Broomley S of Tyne
page.content: Land drops from 200m in S to Tyne valley. In travelling S to N on A68, great sense of space with vista from New Riding Hill bypass of Tyne Valley and hills beyond. Plantations of conifers and isolated farmsteads with mixed crops and pasture lie between the two hamlets of Broomley and Healey. Local sandstone used in practically all buildings. Broomley composed almost entirely of small farm steadings, Healey of a church and stone cottages connected to the Healey estate which is based on mixed farming and forestry. A small saw mill utilises some of the timber for estate purposes, fencing gates, the remainder sold to timber merchants. Red squirrels, badgers, wood ants, foxes, woodland and moorland birds.
